name: N-(4-ethoxyphenyl)-3,3,3-trifluoro-2-(trifluoromethyl)propanamide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3468
Reason: The base molecule, acetanilide, has a melting point of approximately 114 degrees Celsius. The trifluoromethyl group is a strongly electron-withdrawing group due to the high electronegativity of fluorine, which increases intermolecular forces and consequently raises the melting point; this effect might add around +20. The three fluorine atoms on the ethyl side chain also exert a significant electron-withdrawing inductive effect, and their additional molecular weight would contribute to a higher melting point; their cumulative effect may be estimated at around +30. The ethoxy functional group attached to the aromatic ring, through its increased molecular weight and steric bulk, should contribute to raising the melting point further, estimated at about +17. Summing these increments, a predicted melting point can be calculated.
Test (Predicted reason):
The compound N-(4-ethoxyphenyl)-3,3,3-trifluoro-2-(trifluoromethyl)propanamide has several functional groups that influence its melting point. The base unit is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The following adjustments are made to account for the various functional groups: The ethoxy group, which is an ether linkage, is expected to increase the melting point due to the polarity and the ability to form hydrogen bonds, estimated at +20°C. The trifluoromethyl group is highly electronegative and increases the melting point due to strong dipole-dipole interactions, estimated at +30°C. The amide group typically contributes a strong increase in melting point due to hydrogen bonding, estimated at +80°C. The presence of two fluorine atoms on the same carbon (fluoromethyl group) increases the melting point due to the strong electronegativity and the ability to form strong dipole-dipole interactions, estimated at +20°C. Adding these adjustments to the base value gives the predicted melting point.
##Prediction: 180.0
